content: Everything. I marched in the 60s. I've seen rights won and rights threatened. This moment feels critical. They're coming for voting rights again.
participant_profile: M, 71, Retired postal worker, Adamsville, civil rights movement participant
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with what's at stake in this election for Black Georgians.

content: Amen. The new voting laws - limiting drop boxes, making it harder to vote - it's targeted. We know who they're targeting.
participant_profile: F, 67, Retired teacher, Cascade Heights, longtime voter, church member
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with what's at stake in this election for Black Georgians.

content: I work in social services. I see what happens when we don't have representation. The policies that come down affect my clients - healthcare, housing, food assistance. This matters.
participant_profile: F, 42, Social worker, Bankhead, sees systemic issues daily
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with what's at stake in this election for Black Georgians.

content: For my generation, 2020 was awakening. We turned Georgia blue. Now we have to defend it.
participant_profile: M, 26, College senior at Morehouse, first-time voter in 2020
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with what's at stake in this election for Black Georgians.

content: Stacey Abrams built something. Senator Williams continuing it - that's the vision. But we have to show up.
participant_profile: F, 28, Nurse, College Park, first-generation college graduate, activated by 2020
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with what's at stake in this election for Black Georgians.

content: In my barbershop, we talk politics every day. The energy is there. People are engaged. But we can't take anything for granted.
participant_profile: M, 55, Small business owner (barbershop), West End, community fixture
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with what's at stake in this election for Black Georgians.

content: Money. Real talk. Everything costs more. Gas, groceries, rent. I'm working more hours and making less progress.
participant_profile: M, 34, Delivery driver, East Point, occasional voter, economic concerns
preceding_moderator_q: What issues matter most to you?

content: Jobs. Good jobs with benefits. Not gig economy stuff. Real employment.
participant_profile: M, 44, Construction supervisor, College Park, union adjacent
preceding_moderator_q: What issues matter most to you?

content: Representation. Having someone in the Senate who looks like us, who understands our experience. That matters.
participant_profile: F, 31, Marketing coordinator, Midtown, young professional
preceding_moderator_q: What issues matter most to you?

content: Voting rights. If we can't vote, nothing else matters. They know that. That's why they're attacking it.
participant_profile: M, 71, Retired postal worker, Adamsville, civil rights movement participant
preceding_moderator_q: What issues matter most to you?

content: Healthcare. Maternal mortality for Black women is a scandal. We need someone fighting for us.
participant_profile: F, 42, Social worker, Bankhead, sees systemic issues daily
preceding_moderator_q: What issues matter most to you?

content: All of it. Economic justice, civil rights, healthcare, education. It's all connected.
participant_profile: F, 67, Retired teacher, Cascade Heights, longtime voter, church member
preceding_moderator_q: What issues matter most to you?

content: I work at a church. I know Pastor Williams - not well, but I've seen him at conventions, community events. The man is genuine. What you see is what you get.
participant_profile: F, 52, Church administrator, Cascade, knows Williams personally
preceding_moderator_q: Senator Williams is a pastor here in Atlanta. What do you know about him?

content: I've been to his church. When he preaches about justice, about caring for the least of these, you feel it in your bones.
participant_profile: F, 67, Retired teacher, Cascade Heights, longtime voter, church member
preceding_moderator_q: Senator Williams is a pastor here in Atlanta. What do you know about him?

content: He reminds me of the preachers from the movement. Dr. King, Reverend Lowery. That tradition of faith and activism together.
participant_profile: M, 71, Retired postal worker, Adamsville, civil rights movement participant
preceding_moderator_q: Senator Williams is a pastor here in Atlanta. What do you know about him?

content: He came to the shop once, years ago before he was senator. Talked to everybody. Didn't act like he was above anyone.
participant_profile: M, 55, Small business owner (barbershop), West End, community fixture
preceding_moderator_q: Senator Williams is a pastor here in Atlanta. What do you know about him?

content: For young people, he's not just an old-school preacher. He speaks to issues we care about - climate, student debt, justice reform.
participant_profile: M, 26, College senior at Morehouse, first-time voter in 2020
preceding_moderator_q: Senator Williams is a pastor here in Atlanta. What do you know about him?

content: He uses his platform to amplify issues affecting Black women. Maternal health, voting rights. He doesn't just say words.

preceding_moderator_q: Senator Williams is a pastor here in Atlanta. What do you know about him?

content: He's been effective without being flashy. That's hard in Washington.
participant_profile: F, 31, Marketing coordinator, Midtown, young professional
preceding_moderator_q: How has he done as a senator?

content: He delivered on some infrastructure stuff. Jobs projects coming to Georgia. That's real.

content: The man carries himself with dignity. He represents us well. That matters.

content: He's part of a tradition. When I see him in the Senate, I see all the work we did to get there.

preceding_moderator_q: How has he done as a senator?

content: [Shakes head] Come on. This is a joke, right?
participant_profile: M, 55, Small business owner (barbershop), West End, community fixture

content: I mean, I liked watching him play football. But senator? No.
participant_profile: M, 34, Delivery driver, East Point, occasional voter, economic concerns

content: It's actually offensive. Like they think we'll vote for any Black face. He doesn't represent our values.

preceding_moderator_q: What about Blake Harrison?

content: I remember when he was a star. But character is character. What's come out about him... that's disqualifying.

preceding_moderator_q: What about Blake Harrison?

content: The abortion stuff. He's running on pro-life and he's paid for abortions? That's hypocrisy at the highest level.

preceding_moderator_q: What about Blake Harrison?

content: The women coming forward with allegations - we should believe them. He has a pattern.

content: From a professional standpoint, he can't articulate basic policy. He's not prepared for this job.

preceding_moderator_q: What about Blake Harrison?

content: The Republican Party picked him because he was famous. Not because he was qualified. It's cynical.

content: He's funny sometimes? [Laughs] I'm reaching here.
participant_profile: M, 34, Delivery driver, East Point, occasional voter, economic concerns

content: Look, he did come from nothing. That's respectable. But what you do with success matters. He didn't handle it well.

content: I could've respected him if he'd been authentic. But he's playing a character for votes. We see through it.

content: Time. People working two jobs don't have time to stand in line for hours. That's by design.

content: Souls to the Polls. Church mobilization. It works.
